--- title: "Shared Metadata" subtitle: "Share YAML metadata options across multiple documents" description: "In this post I will explain one of the most important features of blog (or generally Quarto) projects: The ability to share YAML metadata options across multiple documents. Shared metadata can be defined at both the blog (project) and directory level." author: "Peter Baumgartner" date: "2024-07-25" image: "pexels-cottonbro-3944311-min1.jpg" image-alt: "Seven different hands grab a slice of a salami pizza cut in eight different pieces." categories: [blog, how-to, quarto] date-modified: "2024-07-25" draft: false lightbox: false engine: knitr --- ![Sharing resources via metadata.
Foto von [cottonbro studio](https://www.pexels.com/de-de/foto/lebensmittel-essen-pizza-hande-3944311/) via [Pexels.com](https://www.pexels.com/)](pexels-cottonbro-3944311-min1.jpg){fig-alt="Seven different hands grab a slice of a salami pizza cut in eight different pieces." width="50%"} ## Introduction Shared YAML metadata can be defined at both the project and directory level: - project level: filename `_quarto.yml` - directory level: filename `_metadata.yml` For more information, see [Project Basics â€“ Quarto Shared Metadata](https://quarto.org/docs/projects/quarto-projects.html#shared-metadata) ## Project Level On the project level, I will change only the provided URLs for my GitHub and Twitter accounts in this first step. :::: {.grid} ::: {.g-col-5} ##### Before My Change ``` {.yml filename="_quarto.yml"} project: type: website website: title: "Life Long Learning Lab" navbar: right: - about.qmd - icon: github href: https://github.com/ - icon: twitter href: https://twitter.com format: html: theme: cosmo css: styles.css ``` ::: ::: {.g-col-7} ##### After My Change ``` {.yml filename="_quarto.yml"} project: type: website website: title: "Life Long Learning Lab" navbar: right: - about.qmd - icon: github href: https://github.com/petzi53/quarto-pb-blog - icon: twitter href: https://x.com/pbaumgartner format: html: theme: cosmo css: styles.css ``` ::: :::: ## Directory Level We have seen in an [previous post](/posts/2024-07-24-default-blog-source-code/#fig-content-posts-folder) that there is a `_metadata.yml` file in the `posts` folder. :::: {.grid} ::: {.g-col-6} ##### Before My Change ``` {.yml filename="_metadata.yml"} # options specified here will apply to all posts in this folder # freeze computational output # (see https://quarto.org/docs/projects/code-execution.html#freeze) freeze: true # Enable banner style title blocks title-block-banner: true ``` ::: ::: {.g-col-6} ##### After My Change ``` {.yml filename="_metadata.yml"} # options specified here will apply to all posts in this folder # freeze computational output # (see https://quarto.org/docs/projects/code-execution.html#freeze) freeze: true # Enable banner style title blocks title-block-banner: false # Author name of all blog posts author: 'Peter Baumgartner' # Table of content settings toc: true toc-depth: 4 page-layout: article ``` ::: :::: The changes are self-explanatory, so short comments will suffice: - `title-block-banner`: I have already removed the title block banner from the home page listings and will disable it for blog posts as well. (I will revise this decision after I have written several posts. Maybe the title block banner is very useful for displaying a short description of the article.) - `author`: All articles in my blog will be written by me. - `toc` and `toc-depth`: I want a table of contents on the right side of the blog post, with a maximum of four levels. (I will revise this decision after I have written some longer articles. Maybe the TOC levels go too deep.) - `page-layout`: I have [already explained](/posts/2024-07-24-default-blog-source-code/#page-layout) the `page-layout: full` directive from the title home page `index.qmd`. Now we want an `article` layout, because it creates a content area with a page-based grid layout that provides margins, areas for sidebars, and a reading width-optimized body region. ## Git and GitHub I will commit these third bulk of changes to Git and my demonstration repository `quarto-pb-blog` [on GitHub](https://github.com/petzi53/quarto-pb-blog).
